answers.answer: I understand how you feel.  My father passed away last year and my mom just had a stroke exactly 2 weeks ago.  I'm 34 and very overwhelmed.  I have nightmares everynight and talk throughout the night.  When I wake up in the morning, everythings just resurfaces.  I haven't stopped having diareha in 2 weeks.  This is just the beginning of my journey with my mom and her stroke.  I have a husband and a 12 year old daughter.  I live in Canada on a landed status and my mom who has had a stroke lives 45 minutes from Canada where I see her daily and at one point will have to come back to stay with her.  My husband can not work in the United States only I can.  I also had just got the job of my life 4 weeks ago and now have to give it up and find a job where my mom lives so I can care for her.  My mom's struggles are multiplied by 5 when looking at mine.  The stroke left her right side immobile and she will have to be taught her communication skills again.  She is unable to speak.  I feel strongly that she knows who I am 99.9% but relatives believe she doesn't know who they are.  My mom sometimes has pain from immobility (spasticity), even though my family and I contiually exercise with her and hope for some recovery.  We also work with her cognitive skills and speech skills.  They say the more we support and work with her the better her ability to recover is.  It is life consuming for me to put this effort in and know that I have a family that also needs my support.  I feel very torn and my husband thinks that I should go back to work at my new job as a sales rep because we need the money.  I fear my husband doesn't understand what I'm up against and how this is going to alter our lives.  I struggle every day in hopes of my moms improvement and my families welfare.  It is hard for me to swallow some days because there is a lump in my throat from fear that something will be lost along the way.  I understand how you feel.  It is hard to see your father suffer and be in pain.  My mom's journey is hard too.   The nurses at my mothers acute rehabilitation center are less than knowledgeable of her condition which makes me sick.  I went in there one day as a nurse was yelling loudly in her ear "Val Do You Want To Lay Down" a couple of times waiting for my mothers response.  I said "WAIT" what are you doing?  My mother can hear fine she is unable to communicate with you because she has had a stroke.  Another nurse didn't use the belt to lift my mother in bed but pulled her up under both arms to put her in bed which can pull her joints out.  These people don't care about my mother.  I want her home where she is comfortable.  I can see in her eyes that she is losing her sense of worth because of the lack of understanding in this rehab facility.  I'm sickened by this and will be talking to the dr.s and rehab people today.  I hate to bring it up because I'm scared that my negative feedback may have an effect on how these nurses continue to treat my mom.  There is more but don't have time.VICKIE
